explanation: Not enough evidence to conclude a definite violation. MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13 is a “should” guideline that recommends qualifying a pointer to point to const when the function does not use the pointer to modify the pointed-to object. In the body of MHD_queue_response the local variable daemon is only read (fields are inspected) and not written through that local pointer, so at first glance it could be made 'const struct MHD_Daemon *daemon'. However, the rule can only be applied if doing so is actually possible given the code base: if daemon is passed to macros/functions (e.g. MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_, MHD_DLOG, MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_) whose prototypes expect a non-const struct MHD_Daemon * (or the macro expands to code that mutates the object), then declaring daemon as a pointer-to-const would be incompatible without changing those APIs. The supplied code and test do not show the prototypes/definitions of those macros/functions, so you cannot prove that the local pointer cannot be const-qualified or that making it const would be acceptable. Therefore the agent A’s claim — that this omission is a MISRA 8.13 violation — is not demonstrated by the provided evidence. At best this is a suggestion for improvement (make daemon a pointer-to-const if all callees permit it), not a proven MISRA violation.
